UfRJaULy.question: (see annex) You are transitioning from the STAR at Aberdeen Dyce for a localiser/DME approach to Runway16 and following the procedure shown in the annex. At what point are you permitted to descend from 2500ft to 2300ft?

options.text: When the LOC deviation bar is within half scale deflection
when you have established communication with ATC
When the LOC deviation bar is less than full scale deflection

HBPi1F0i.question: A log-on is required for the following service:

eAD1zjrx.question: Which of the following procedures must be adopted if, on a flight under IFR conditions using a NAVSTAR/GPS satellite navigation system receiver, the position fix obtained from the GPS receiver differs from the position of conventional navigation systems by an unacceptable amount?

options.text: It may be continued using conventional navigation systems
The pilot must determine the reason for the deviation and correct the error or switch off the faulty system
It must be continued under VFR conditions
It may be continued using NAVSTAR/GPS; prior to the next flight all systems must be checked

0EPhBRoB.question: Which statement about RNAV-routes is correct?

options.text: A method of navigation which permIts aircraft operation on any desired flight path.
All waypoints of RNAV-routes are called phantom stations
RNAV-routes are only used in terminal areas in order to make more efficient use of the approach and landing facilities of an airport
In general RNAV-routes coincide with standard routes in order to make optimum use of the available VOR/DME-stations

sfdyw1Qr.question: You are on a planned approach to Longyearbyen airport in Svalbard. Since you are too far north you do not have enough satellites in view to perform a GNSS approach and landing. Which equipment can you rely upon instead?

eonF7BST.question:
Which of the following may be used for minimum RNAV performance:  
1. NDB  
2. IRS/INS  
3. VOR/DME  
4. GPS

3O24rITR.question: A 3-dimensional RNAV system has capability in:

options.text: The horizontal plane and in the vertical plane.
The horizontal plane and a speed management system.
The horizontal plane, in the vertical plane and a timing function.
The horizontal plane and a cruise management system.

fjBD5UCl.question: A pilot is planning to fly an RNP 1 STAR (Standard Terminal Arrival) but notices that one of the waypoints is missing in the FMS readout of the procedure, when comparing to the chart. It appears that due to an error, the missing waypoint is NOT defined in the FMS database. As a result of this error, the pilot may...

options.text: NOT fly the planned procedure and must request an alternative STAR.
create a waypoint based on the known latitude and longitude of the missing waypoint.
create a waypoint based on a radial and distance from a nearby VOR DME station.
fly the STAR provided there are NO gaps in the coding of the arrival.

iszRf4jm.question:
Which of the following are some of the required navigation functionalities of RNAV and RNP specifications?

1. Continuous indication of lateral deviation2. Continuous indication of vertical deviation3. Distance/bearing to the active waypoint4. Groundspeed or time to the active waypoint5. Navigation data storage6. Navigation data modification

bIceFSZP.question: Which of the following PBN navigation specifications allows the pilot to manually enter the navigational data into the RNAV system database?

3dQuSTMA.question: “X” in RNAV X or RNP X is the (1) ___ navigation accuracy (total system error) in (2) ___, which is expected to be achieved at least (3) ___ of the flight time by the population of aircraft operating within the airspace, route or procedure.

oBnhewV7.question: Which of the following factors affects the minimum spacing requirements of an ATS route?

CvK89lAQ.question: Why is strict adherence to flight director guidance important when manually flying a radius to fix (RF) leg? The flight director...

options.text: is required to provide the necessary level of guidance and precision during the turn.
allows the pilot to cross-check the DME arc guidance along the RF procedure.
provides guidance based on a fixed radius calculated with current TAS and bank angle.
must be used in place of the autopilot as it provides more precise guidance.

Q8U086SS.question: You are preparing for a descent and ATC asks you to arrive at a specific point and at specific timeWhat RNAV capability do you need to comply with such instruction?

vdYAExfI.question: Within the PBN concept, "accuracy" can be defined as ...

options.text: a comparison between the required position and the true position.
having a total system error that is expected to be achieved at least 50% of the time
being within 5 NM laterally and within 100 ft vertically of the required position
being in compliance with the reference ellipsoid WGS-95

d1Kth85t.question: Within the PBN concept, which of the following statements is correct?

options.text: In the approach phases of flight, PBN accommodates both linear and angular laterally guided operations.
For oceanic/remote, en-route and terminal phases of flight, PBN is limited to operations with angular laterally guided operations.
In the approach phases of flight, PBN is limited to operations with guidance to fly the ILS procedure.
For oceanic/remote, en-route and terminal phases of flight, PBN accommodates both linear and angular laterally guided operations.

eVii5Byi.question:
A flight at 74°N is conducted in IMC at night and due to the constellation of the satellites, the flight crew decided to fly an RNP APCH to LNAV/VNAV minimum, based on baro-VNAV and horizontal guidance from the GNSS. The published minimum temperature for this approach is -8 °C and the temperature reported by ATIS is -6 °C. Your aircraft is not fitted with an automatic temperature compensation.
While flying the final approach, ATC suddenly instructs you to commence a go-around due to terrain separation. What has happened?

options.text: The actual temperature is lower than -8 °C, resulting in wrong indications for the baro-VNAV approach.
Possible glide slope signal or localiser interferences from a nearby runway.
Signal loss or weak signals of the GNSS due to the high latitude.

MNVvTN49.question: Which of the following lists information required to input a waypoint or Phantom Station into a basic VOR/DME-based Area Navigation System?

options.text: Radial and distance from a VOR/DME to the waypoint or Phantom Station
Radials from a minimum of two VORs to the waypoint or Phantom Station
Magnetic Track and distance from the aircraft to the waypoint or Phantom Station
Magnetic Track and distance to a VOR/DME from the waypoint or Phantom Station

aBtWmR8U.question: Which of the following factors are used to define area navigation (RNAV) or required navigation performance (RNP) system performance requirements? - Accuracy - Performance - Integrity - Application - Continuity

t9ljh3PA.question: Which one of the following inputs to an Area Navigation System (R-NAV) comes from an external, not on-board, system?

Q0HWpBKD.question: Why must the flight director be used for guidance when flying an RF leg without the autopilot?

options.text: The RF leg is based on a fixed radius turn with guidance calculated by the aircraft's RNAV system.
The RNP system uploads the RF procedure to the FAC, which then provides guidance via the flight director.
The flight director displays guidance based on the information received from ground-based transmitters.
The flight director will give a visual and audible alert if the actual navigation performance exceeds the RNP during the RF leg.

KB76C1oX.question: Which of the following terms refers to a fixed radius path for en-route sections using Performance Based Navigation (PBN)?

kp2S2i1d.question: With regard to the FMS navigational database, which of the following statements is correct?

options.text: The navigational database is read-only, but space exists for crew-created navigational data.
The navigational database is read only. It is not possible for the crew to add to it in any way.
The navigational database is updated as required, or annually if no updates have been made in the previous 12 months.
The crew can change the content of the navigational database at any time.

dYpmPOGk.question: Which of the following is a requirement for Required Navigation Performance (RNP)operations?Area navigation that includes the requirements for..

options.text: integrating ATC surveillance monitoring and alerting.

options.text: It is a radar precision approach available at military fields only.

3D approach operations are very common nowadays. Which of the following options belongs to this type of approach?
1. RNP APCH (GNSS and baro VNAV) 
 2. GLS

options.text: horizontal plane + it has a timing function.

Within PBN operations, what is the make-up of the "Total System Error" (TSE)?PDE = Path Definition Error 
 FTE = Flight Technical Error 
 NSE = Navigation System Error

eC67RQIL.question: A two-dimensional Area Navigation (2D RNAV) system is able to navigate in

options.text: both the horizontal and vertical planes.

ddrAAtUA.question: A pilot is planning an IFR flight using RNAV. One part of the planned route requires RNP 1. This part could be...

options.text: a low level helicopter en-route segment.
an en-route segment in a continental area only.
a high level en-route segment in an oceanic area.
an en-route segment in a remote area between FL140 and FL280.

z8wfgRK4.question: Which RNP can be used in all phases of flight except for en-route oceanic/remote and final approach phases and is intended primarily for helicopters?

MzwicOkQ.question:
Which of the following are the components of PBN?

1. The NAVAID infrastructure2. The aircraft type3. The navigation specification4. Communications5. The navigation application6. ATS surveillance7. ATM

wCzhhXow.question: For an operation in NAT HLA airpsace, which RNP is required for a 50 NM lateral offset?

mTcbmfX3.question: Which of the following statements is correct regarding RNAV/RNP navigation specifications and any requirements for on-board performance monitoring and alerting?

options.text: RNP specifications include the requirement for on-board performance monitoring and alerting.
RNP specifications include the requirement for ATC surveillance to alert the flight crew if systems performance does not comply.
RNAV specifications include the requirement for on-board performance monitoring and alerting.
RNAV specifications include the requirement for on-board and ground-based performance monitoring and alerting.

vn4l1LIK.question: Your aircraft is able to conduct RNP APCH. Are you allowed to conduct RNP2?

options.text: Not necessarily. First, establish the aircraft eligibility.
Yes, navigation databases are the same for all RNP operations.
Yes, provided that clearance is obtained from ATC.
Yes, if you can perform an RNP APCH, you can conduct any RNP operation.

0olSIQdK.question: Which of the following statements best describes PBN? Performance-based navigation...

options.text: requires the development of sensor-specific routes and procedures.
is similar to conventional navigation, requiring ground-based infrastructure.
is based on sensor-specific navigation specifications.

dLZiWyi5.question: To which performance does the concept of RNP apply?

options.text: To navigation performance within an airspace.
To navigation performance within an airspace using satellite navigation systems only.
To navigation performance on RNAV routes only.
To navigation performance within an airspace and a specific time-interval.

uFnYLmpz.question: Which of the following statements is true about RNP / RNAV navigation specifications?

options.text: Aircraft approved for the more stringent accuracy requirements may not necessarily meet some of the functional requirements of the navigation specification that has a less stringent accuracy requirement.
Aircraft approved for the more stringent functional requirements automatically meet the accuracy requirements of the navigation specification that has a less stringent functional requirement.
Aircraft approved for the more stringent accuracy requirements automatically meet the functional requirements of the navigation specification that has a less stringent accuracy requirement.
Accuracy requirements are always similar to the functional requirements.

b1tYwFG5.question: Which of the following is one of the functions of the Computer in a basic RNAV system?

options.text: It transfers the information given by a VOR/DME station into tracking and distance indications to any chosen Phantom Station/waypoint
It checks the ground station accuracy using a built-in test programme
It calculates cross track information for NDB approaches
It automatically selects the two strongest transmitters for the Area-Nav-Mode and continues working by memory in case one of the two necessary station goes off the air

Lj16I6oq.question: A pilot is flying between two waypoints defined by suitably located VOR/DMEs. Equipped with a simple 2D RNAV system, this pilot:

options.text: Reads cross track error and the distance to go on CDI or HSI.
Enters relative position between his aircraft and the VOR/DMEs on CDU to calculate the cross track error.
Reads VOR/DME bearing and distance on CDI or HSI to compute himself the cross track error.
Must update any altitude change in RNAV system to have correct cross track error.

JYUjPK0z.question: With respect to navigation error components, the Total System Error (TSE) in Performance Based Navigation  (PBN) is...

options.text: a measure of the navigation accuracy.
zero if the Navigation System Error (NSE) is zero.
a fixed value indicating the lateral navigation error.
a value for the accuracy of the 3-dimensional position.

P3cvFFzd.question: Which of the following PBN approaches is a non-precision instrument approach procedure designed for 2D approach operations?

options.text: RNP APCH to LNAV / VNAV minima

iRshWdZ6.question: A 2D RNAV system provides guidance in:

FBMNkxaw.question: A phantom station (as used in a 2D RNAV-system) is:

options.text: A waypoint defined by a radial and a DME-distance from a VOR/DME-station.
A waypoint defined by two DME-distances from two different VOR/DME-stations.
A non-existing VOR/DME-station defined by two DME distances.
An existing VOR/DME-station created in the memory of the Navigation Computer Unit of the RNAV-system.

fdCvH0vp.question: A Flight Management System (FMS) can provide an Estimated Position Error (EPE) that is often used to check against the Required Navigation Performance (RNP) value of a procedure or airspace. Which of these best describes the EPE?

options.text: A measure of the reasonableness and accuracy of the given flight management position by applying a specific set of rules to the available navigation inputs.
A measure of the accuracy of the flight management system for navigation, and is demonstrated during initial certification of the aircraft.
An average of the navigation errors computed by two or more FMSS when compared against each other and subsequently applied as a correction to improve position accuracy.
A sum of all the navigational errors accumulated over time that may be used as a measure of the performance of the navigation system after a flight.

WLv0sEtQ.question: A pilot is planning to conduct a flight under the specifications of PBN. An RNP approach to LNAV/VNAV minima may only be flow with vertical guidance...

options.text: from an ILS or MLS glide slope.

MXxe4BtZ.question: Which term refers to the difference between the aircraft's estimated position and actual position in the context of PBN?

qy8RM08i.question:
A flight crew prepares to execute an RNP APCH. Which of the following actions shall they take?
  1. Load the procedure from a valid aircraft navigation database,
  2. Insert each waypoint's coordinates, into the navigation system,
  3. Cross-check the waypoint sequence with a valid approach chart,
  4. Cross-check the lateral path with a VOR overlay approach.

sdH5liuU.question: Which of the following statements is true about the navigation specification RNP 1?

options.text: RNP 1 is limited to use on STARs, SIDs, the initial and intermediate segments of Instrument Approach Procedures and the missed approach after the initial climb phase.
It may be used for the initial part of a STAR outside 30 NM and above MSA.
RNP 1 is used in all phases of flight except for oceanic/remote and final approach, and is primarily intended for helicopter operations.
It permits a range of scalable RNP lateral and longitudinal navigation accuracies.

leav171k.question: Which statement is true regarding an offset flight path?

options.text: It allows the crew to specify a lateral offset from a defined route
It allows the crew to specify a vertical offset from a defined route
An offset flight path is used for holding
An offset flight path is used for parallel approaches in terminal areas

huL1RHNW.question: Why is it necessary for both pilots and air traffic controllers to be aware of the capabilities and performance of RNAV and RNP systems when aircraft enter and operate in a particular airspace?

options.text: To be confident that the aircraft is capable of navigating with the appropriate accuracy to ensure adherence to procedures and separation.
To be confident that all aircraft follow the same path and follow the same turn radius, giving the same predictable track-keeping performance.
It ensures that all aircraft entering are capable of following the procedures and therefore reduces workload by eliminating the need for monitoring.
It ensures that both pilots and air traffic controllers are confident that the aircraft will follow published tracks also in the event of systems downgrade.

DqlxuXBr.question: Which statement is true if you compare raw data with computed data?

options.text: Conventional radio navigation is based on raw data like information from navigation aids and measured air data.
Raw data are based on computed data.
Sensor-based data is often referred to raw data. PBN is mainly based on such data.
PBN is based on computed data which is highly sensor-specific.

SNksM95I.question: You are briefing an approach to an airfield which uses PBN operations. Which kind of specifications do you encounter in the NAT HLA? - RNP 10 and RNP 4 - RNAV 10 - RNP 2 - RNAV 2

JJWfIQqh.question: Which statement is true relating to the comparison of raw data and computed data (in PBN)?

options.text: conventional radio navigation is based on raw data from specific NAVAIDs such as VOR, DME or NDB
raw data is based on computed data
PBN is based on computed data which is highly sensor specific
sensor based data is often referred to as raw data. PBN is mainly based on such data

sSp1ghQw.question: Which of the following are components of PBN? - The NAVAID infrastructure - Pilot training - The navigation specification - Integrity control - The navigation application

dEzr67sw.question: Which of the following statements, in relation to PBN operational approvals in accordance with the European Regulations on Air Operations, is correct?

options.text: Only certain PBN specifications require an operational approval.
The PBN specifications that require operational approval are MCTOM (Maximum Certified Take-Off Mass)-dependent.
The PBN specifications that require operational approval are operator-dependent.
All PBN specifications require an operational approval.

GVzJR6Gv.question: ... is the capability that the specified system performance will be maintained for the duration of a phase of operation, presuming that the system was available at the beginning of that phase of operation and was predicted to operate throughout the operation.
